awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Laura Cladek is "Harmonic Analysis." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California-Los Angeles, and the sponsoring scientist is Terrence Tao.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
During my NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship at UCLA, I have made research contributions to several areas. My interests in Euclidean harmonic analysis are largely motivated by a central tree of conjectures which include the celebrated local smoothing, Bochner-Riesz, restriction, and Kakeya conjectures. This tree of conjectures have been shown to have deep connections with incidence geometry, geometric measure theory, algebraic geometry, and combinatorics. My second main interest in this area is the study of pseudodifferential operators and singular integrals, which have many important applications in microlocal analysis and the study of partial differential equations.


My research in geometric measure theory and incidence geometry is largely focused on the Kakeya problem and surrounding related problems such as the Falconer distance set problem and the Buffon Needle problem. These problems have foundational applications in harmonic analysis and have spurred the development of a diverse variety of techniques, including entropy methods, combinatorial approaches, and model-theoretic approaches using tools from modern algebraic geometry.

My work in additive combinatorics centers around structural theorems and additive combinatorics in a fractal or continuum setting. A central topic of focus in additive combinatorics is the quantitative characterization of subsets of discrete abelian groups that ``behave well" with respect to the operation of addition; a fully satisfactory characterization is far from complete, and progress in this direction would lead to major advancements on a variety of other open problems in the area.

My second main goal is making contributions to areas of diversity, equity, and inclusion by taking on leadership and advocacy roles. I have also made contributions to DEI at UCLA by partaking in mentorship opportunities for students from underrepresented groups, participating in interviews at MSRI centered around issues of DEI, and organizing the joint UCLA-Caltech seminar.

 


Last Modified: 03/02/2022
Modified by: Laura Cladek
